content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												Nidhogg is a side-scrolling, “holy♥♥♥♥♥♥what-the-hell-is-going-on,” mixed with “I-don’t-know-why-I-can’t-stop-laughing.” It is played in a tug-of-war style fashion where the objective is to reach the end of the stage before your opponent reaches theirs by playing a friendly game of…fencing? The mechanics are simple to learn and run with, but definitely take at least moderate skill to master. From fencing, to CQC, you’ll find that there’s quite a few ways to maim your foes and book it to the end stage (have you stuck someone on your sword and moved it around yet? Brutal!). A game like this could be daunting had it been slow – the speed and fluid motions of the gameplay really shine in this high speed fencing brawl. A game like this reminds me of a single-player buy that you kill about an hour or two on and then never touch it again (unless you achievement hunt). The multiplayer adds so much more to the game, including at least several more hours you can kill in multiplayer. I’m not sure I’m 100% sold on a $15 dollar tag for the game. Granted it IS fun, and there IS a chance that I could play this for longer than I’m advertising, but I honestly can see this game sitting idly by once the novelty wears off. The part that sucks is close range strafing with your opponent. Too soft and you don’t do what you were hoping to do. Too hard and you just ran yourself right onto your opponents sword.Beautiful pixel graphics, interesting mechanics, and a unique game overall with brilliant music, I definitely recommend this game to those interested in taking a chance on something fresh and original. If you're worried about the price, catch it on sale. Between $4.99-7.99 is a must buy, $7.99-9.99 is what I would have expected.

												8/10Thanks Gaben for making the summer sale and I managed to buy this game on discount at an EXTREMELY low price ($2.99). This game is generally fun and you can play with your friends in a party, or whatever. I would recommend you to use a controller and play it on bigscreen as it is generally more fun and easier to control.The goal of this game, is to reach the goal sides set on teh side of both sides. You can repeatedly kill each other, until one reaches the end. (And you get a dragon to eat you for winning)There is a range of levels where you can entertain yourself and your friends with and have a good laugh. If you don't have friends or if they are too busy doing something else, you can play against the bot (singleplayer). The bot was also decent to play against. It wasn't too hard and it wasn't too easy. The online mode is messed up.Each map was fun to play with unique features. For example the map Mine, had transportation belts which either brings the player forward to allow him to reach the goal side quicker or push him/her back and make the progress slower. And the map Wild, had tall grass for the players to hide in. The graphics is good for a game like this. I'd prefer it to be pixelated and it gives it an arcade feel. The truth is, it doesn't need detailed graphics. For player movement, it was great. You can stab your opponent, throw swords, roll underneath players, disarm players from their swords and if you got disarmed yourself, you can punch the other player to death. If you fell down a pit and managed to grab a wall, keep on wall-kicking and get yourself out.And lastly, it gives a player tutorial which helps you learn about the controls, how to stab, throw, disarm, etc. Overall, this game is great and if you want a good laugh and have an enjoyable time by yourself or with your frieds, I'd definitely get it as it is on discount. Get 1 copy for your friends too!

Posted: June 11, 2014
												dont buy this game. its not worth 15 dollars. 10, maybe, but probably more like 5. The controls are screwed up to the point were its incredibly hard to control your guy. The mechanics allow your enemy to stab you from the exact same distance you TRIED to stab him. In fact, overall the mechanic where you NEED to be doing a specific action (in this case, sprint and duck/up) to either throw your sword, or do a leg sweep, is stupid, and only has a chance to work. I have died so many times as I have attempted to perform a sword throw, and rather have just raised my sword stupidly. additionally, the game system itself is flawed. Nidhogg uses a system called right of way to determin the winner. This means that when someone kills the other, they can just continuosly run to the endzone of the level, winning. Only one person can have right of way, but the person without spawns in front of the person with right of way whenever they die. First of all, this system is broken, as whoever has right of way can just jump over the enemy whenever they spawn. The spawning itself is flawed too, as you will find yourself having to kill someone three times just to move five feet, because they respawn the second after you kill them. These game mechanics arent broken, they just make the game frustrating rather than fun. Overall, this game is like a math test, it tests for skill, certainly, but its never fun, ever.

Posted: June 22, 2014
												Before now, games that duplicate the twitchy tactical joy of fencing have been nonexistant. They still stubbornly refuse to exist, but Nidhogg does a fantastic job of hinting at the complexity while totally failing to be a realistic fencing game. Lunging, disarming, punching, sweeping the leg, divekicking, and throwing the damn sword at your opponent are the only options you have but they make for a deep and textured fight. There is always a different technique to master and there are players out there that will take the fight in directions you never suspected in single player. The pace is fast but the response is so tight you never feel out of control. I love fighting protracted battles back and forth over a stage and then realizing the level is soaked in your and your opponent's blood. I love blitter feedback, the whole game looks like an Amiga demo.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												This is one of those couch co-op games where you test endurance more than skill.The game is a "tug-of-war" fencing game. What that means is, you can only progress if you were the last one to net the kill, and the entire goal isn't to kill the foe after that- it's to sprint to your goal. So long as you have the "Go" arrow you can progress, otherwise your opponent can. The goal of the game is to protect yourself while you're progressing and to be as aggressive as possible when you're defending.The game has very simple mechanics- Jump, lunge/throw, raise sword, lower sword, duck, roll, kick, flying kick, etc. What makes the game interesting is these simple mechanics blend so nicely... however it does lead to some intense frustration as you THINK you got the hit but your opponent was just ONE TINY MILLISECOND ahead of you and stabs you first.It's definitally a fun game that you can pick up with  a friend, but extended play is nerve-wrecking and requires a great deal of patience.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												Nidhogg is a small game developed by an indie developer Messhof. While the game isn’t the longest one I have ever played, it is definitely THE best local multiplayer game I have played in a long time. You can literally spend countless hours playing the local multiplayer against your friends.In Nidhogg there is only one objective , kill your opponent by out-stabbing them by using only three sets of stances, high, middle and low. Maneuvers such as, rolling, dive-kicking, neck-snapping and sword-throwing are also at your disposal. While it may sound simple at first, the game is really hard to master, and sometimes it gets a little bit frustrating when you get stabbed couple times in a row.After you kill your enemy you have to run to the right in order to advance to next level, the enemy can do the same thing, if you get killed, he can run to the opposite direction, this will get you back to the previous screen, and this gets really annoying because sometimes the enemy instead of fighting you, will just run past you just to get you back to the previous screen. Each ‘level’ is divided into couple smaller ones. In single player, there is a total of 17 AI opponents, the first one being the easiest and the last one, the toughest(I don’t know if that’s true but when I’ve played it, the game got harder every time with each AI opponent). At the end of each level your character is eaten by a giant dragon-like creature, by the name of Nidhogg, you can’t avoid it though(trust me, I’ve tried), I don’t know what’s the point of that but It’s kind of hilarious and random.The art style is what I love the most about this game, it has that surreal look to it, kind of like Hotline Miami. The player animations are also worth mentioning because of how smooth and realistic they are, and also it feels really satisfying when you stab someone.On the other hand, the game also has some flaws, one of them is the online multiplayer, it is seriously lacking in features and is very unstable, I kept being disconnected from matches, and I have experienced serious lag during several online matches. You can’t even properly communicate with your opponent because the chat can’t handle longer messages.As I have said before, the single-player consists of 17 AI opponents, which is great but the same can’t be said about the level variety, there is only 3 or 4 different levels which are re-used during the 17 battles in the single-player. I really wish that there was more variety in level design, maybe we’ll get them in later updates.Nonetheless, If you enjoy playing games with your friends then this game is for you but If you don’t like the local multiplayer I would still recommend sure the game isn’t very long, but the multiplayer is still there, it might be a bit lackluster but who knows maybe the devs will add some new features to the online multiplayer.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												Full review: http://www.cublikefoot.com/review/nidhogg-game-review/Nidhogg, also referred to as Fencing Simulator 2014 (by me, at least), is an excellent example of what a casual, multiplayer indie game should be. Be prepared to engage in very fast-paced swordplay, with friends of course.The objective in Nidhogg is very simple: reach the end of the map on the enemy's side before he/she can reach your end of the map. Upon reaching the end of the map, you're promptly eaten by an Alaskan Bullworm. No idea why, but that signals your victory. However, a lone enemy stands in the way, ready to commence fencing at any given moment. This is where the real fun in the game lies, the fighting. Well, that's basically what the game is, so there's a plus.There are three stances that one can take whilst wielding a sword in Nidhogg: Low, mid, and high. If your opponent attacks you low, and your stance is low, then you block their attack. This applies to the other two stances as well. There's also a stance that you can take if you just hold your sword up high. This stance is only used to prepare for throwing the sword, which, when thrown, can be deflected if your opponent has a mid or high stance active. Once you're without a sword, you must revert to your fists, which don't always help out much. However, you can pick up a fallen sword.The game has a very minimalistic style to it. The characters are very low-res, solid-color sprites. This is an interesting style for such a game and it does add to the fun a bit on a certain stage, the Cloud stage. Because of the game's style, it is very difficult to see where each character is on this map, which is both a good and bad thing! All that said, the game does have one massive flaw. That flaw being the complete lack of content. For a game that has been in development for several years, I would at least expect more than four maps. Four years and only four maps? Very disappointing.Nidhogg, overall, is just an excellent game. Highly recommended if you have a friend to play it with!

												Nidhogg is a great game where two players engage in a fencing duel of throwing, kicking, and stabing. This game can easy for two players to play on one computer (for instance one player using w,a,s,d and another up, down, left, right). You can set up tournaments where players can battle in a series of battles determining the best player. Nidhogg includes has a single-player mode. In singleplayer you fight different computers in hope of getting the fastest time. One great feature is variants where you can customize the gameplay for a new experience. Variants include time limit, low gravity, turbo mode, slow mode, boomerang swords, and more. I would highly recomend this game for any group of two or more people.

												I first played Nidhogg after dinner at a friend's house. Things were looking boring so I whipped out my laptop that everyone could gather round to watch me play Freecell.Luckily, someone grabbed it from me and logged onto their Steam account to set up a tournament of this game.You each control a fencer and have to kill the other guy then run across their body to get to the next screen. Do this enough times and you win.You can throw your sword at your opponent's face, disarm them, and even roll like a ninja/bowling ball along the floor before sweeping out their legs and pulling the still-beating heart out of their body.It's great.And it has graphics like on an old-timey computer, but really slick animation, so the whole style is warm and milky all over your face. Haha! But seriously, the animation is great. I heard the guy spent four years on it. Or the game as a whole. I dunno. But it was four years well spent whatever.Oh, and what's the Nidhogg? You'll find out. Just whatever you do - and I can't stress this enough - don't get eaten by it!

												I first played Nidhogg after dinner at a friend's house. Things were looking boring so I whipped out my laptop that everyone could gather round to watch me play Freecell.Luckily, someone grabbed it from me and logged onto their Steam account to set up a tournament of this game.You each control a fencer and have to kill the other guy then run across their body to get to the next screen. Do this enough times and you win.You can throw your sword at your opponent's face, disarm them, and even roll like a ninja/bowling ball along the floor before sweeping out their legs and pulling the still-beating heart out of their body.It's great.And it has graphics like on an old-timey computer, but really slick animation, so the whole style is warm and milky all over your face. Haha! But seriously, the animation is great. I heard the guy spent four years on it. Or the game as a whole. I dunno. But it was four years well spent whatever.Oh, and what's the Nidhogg? You'll find out. Just whatever you do - and I can't stress this enough - don't get eaten by it!

content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
 A Nidhogg is a mythical creature in Norse mythology which is a giant, man-eating serpent. In this game two fencers battle it out for the glory of being eaten by the Nidhogg in the ultimate sacrifice to the gods, or something like that. GAMEPLAY I have to admit when i first started playing I had no idea what the heck was going on. Bashing random keys hoping something would happen, but the AI continued to outsmart me; Keyboard is not recommended. When I used my controller (steam controller works great! xbox too) the controls seemed much easier to get the hang of but it is still complex enough to keep me interested. You can choose a high, centered or lower stance to stab your opponent.Just aim above or below your opponent  right?  wrong.Besides stances there are a ton of strategies for you to employ: running, rolling, jumping, jump kicking, sword throwing.If you're feeling really daring there's even a way to disarm your opponent, but beware you can still get knocked out and strangled to death (seriously) and lose the arrow.The arrow is something that's been there in loads of games, but it works pretty well in this game. At the start there is no arrow until one of the fencers kills the other. Then the power of the arrow is all yours and you don't have to actually kill your opponent. Then run for your life! the Nidhogg awaits! SOUND Meh. The soundtrack is more or less what you'd expect, I like it :PThe sword swings and the death screams are what you're hearing most of the time, and they are fantastic. Not to the point where they are haunting, but they aren't silly either. And the sweet sound of the crowds after you have bested your opponent is one of the best feelings in this game. GRAPHICS Well lets be honest here, if you've already looked at the game its clear that graphics are not the main focus. You could probably redraw this game in MS Paint. But hey, its an art choice, right?The effect of the pixel art is kind of nice and makes the game feel a bit unique (to me at least, if you play a lot of pixel art games then maybe not) and as you spill your opponent's blood, or they yours, you notice the area becoming absolutely soaked in blood, which is also the same colour as its respective carrier before it was splattered everywhere making it easy to see who the real lamb to the slaughter is. CONCLUSION It's a complete package, no DLC adds a few points in my book, death screams and for added fun, you can always roleplay as the fencer (en garde!) with a friend if that's your thing. Challenging single player modes, and multiplayer is double the fun. 7/10. Very replayable and keeps me coming back too.Get this game if you like stabbing people, annoying your friends, or if you want to play it with me because I love this game for all the right reasons.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												It took me a while to understand this game. It seemed clunky, weird, too based on random chance and the luck of finding an opening as I charged blindly forward. I didn't get what I was doing wrong. Then, on my third run through the wilds level, my opponent and I both disarmed one another simultaneously. I didn't have a weapon, and neither did he. So I did what seemed sane: I tried to stab him anyways. And we started boxing. Then he punched me backwards into the crop fields, where I had seen my weapon land. Frantically, I searched the stalks of wheat, looking for the familiar silver glint of my weapon. Behind me, he leapt into the air, ready to land upon me where I lay and smash my face into the dirt that would be my unceremonius grave. And at the last possible moment, my hand met the cold steel of my blade, and I spun, holding my weapon high —He landed squarely on the tip of sword, violently impaled by his own momentum. And in that moment, I understood. This game was exactly as frantic, exactly as crazy and snap-reflex-based as a real fencing match, between real swordsmen. The controls might not have the finesse of an actual human arm holding an epee, but the mechanics, the pacing; these are pitch-perfect, and evoke the same thrilling adrenaline rush that whipping an actual rapier around in a clumsy attempt at defense gave me in my teenage fencing lessons (my local community center offered some pretty rad summer programs). The key is to treat combat in Nidhogg with the same sort of gravity you would in real life. Take small, inching steps toward your enemy. Change stances freely, and attack opportunistically, when given a wide opening. And only throw your sword at the oppenent when it's the only move you've got left.It's possible to beat Nidhogg without really knowing how to play it. The game is pretty forgiving, and you have an unlimited number of attempts for each stage, meaning you can essentially grind your way towards victory if you're really determined. But it's immensely satisfying to clear a level without losing a life by trouncing the bevy of foes that stand in your way one-by-one. So practice up, and prove you've got what it takes to be a winner.

Posted: May 19, 2015
												Before you start playing this game, don't be confused, LOCAL multiplayer is really it's strong suit. Now I don't have many hours played on my account, but I've played this game plenty on a friend's, and it really is an excellent game. It's definitely a game of skill. No outside forces are going to impact whether or not you come out the victor, it's simply you against your opponent, and occasionally taking advantage of your surroundings. The swordplay is easy to get used to but hard to master, and when you snap the neck of an enemy that's on the ground, it's amazingly satisfying. The visuals are a retro style done right, and the music and sound effects make the game come alive. One of the best local multiplayer experiences I've ever had. However, connections with online multiplayer seem to be giving other people problems. (I don't have experience with this myself, as I've only played it locally) so if this is a turn-off for you, keep that in mind. If the local multiplayer experience is enough to warrant the $15 for you, go for it. If not, get the game on sale. One way or another, Don't pass up on this game.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												Do not buy this game for online play. You will be disappointed.I love looking for new games to play with friends, and I was ecstatic to see this finally released. The gameplay is fantastically unique: You fight past your opponent to run to their 'endzone.' Killing them is not always necessary; you can just run past them, but it'll usually get you killed. After all, combat is what the game was made for.When fencing, there are three different stances you can take (low, mid, high), which can be used for parrying, or, if swift enough, disarming. But if you get disarmed, you can still roll under your opponent, kick them off their feet, snap their neck, and take their sword. But then they respawn at the other end again! So here's where you just chuck your sword into their head and pick it up again as you run past.This is one of very few games where I have wanted to practice different techniques, guards, and attacks. The depth of gameplay is great (Even if there are only four stages), and the idea is unique. The one downside is the online play, which, more often than not, gives players too much lag to even be playable.I wouldn't recommend this if you don't have friends to play with locally, but if you do, enjoy!

Posted: January 17, 2014
												Between the parrying, disarming, dodging, rolling, wall-jumping, punching, sweep-kicking, throwing your sword in rage to kill a fleeing adversary, having the satisfaction of idly jiggling your sword into your impaled foe's innards, and ultimately coming down to fisticuffs until you tear out your opponent's heart (or, as so often happens, they tear YOUR heart out), this game allows the players and spectators alike to enjoy the chaos of swordfighting in a 2-D world in good ol' fashioned, nitty-gritty one-on-one PvP, done arcade style and done right. Highly recommended for a game to settle a beef, make wagers, record the inevitable rage of at least one of the combatants, or just to pass the time with a gruesome yet addicting game of pixelated tug-of-war (just replacing the ropes with rapiers). 9.5/10 (because there is just a tad bit of lag occasionally online, but that's partly my weak internet connection).

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
												There's something to be said about a game that feels as balanced as Nidhogg does. Every offense has its countering defensive stance, every defense has an offensive move to get around it, and none of them require any more or less effort than the other, making it a simple game of preparation, reflexes, and psychology; the true essence of a fighting game.The graphics could be described as 'minimal', or it could be described as 'clear'. I choose to view it the latter way. All necessary information is communicated in an understandable fashion without sacrificing artistic integrity. Daedelus' soundtrack provides an excellent support to the atmosphere of the game and its individual levels, from the intense and aggressive Wilds, to the tense and deliberate Mines, and the quick and nimble Clouds.Nidhogg's design is flawless in nearly every aspect, the only regrets being the lack of content. But why should you care about that, when you can throw a sword at someone to force them to block high, roll underneath them while grabbing a sword, then stab them in the back in a series of grand maneuvers that will make you feel like a god among men?

Posted: October 4, 2014
												I strongly recommend this game. Even with the people complaining about lag in the forums, I played it with my friend and had no problems at all. And being a huge fencing fan, I think this game is perfect in the format it was made. You really need to approach the fight strategically or you'll get your derrière sistematically handed to you. The game is one hit kill when armed with sword and when disarmed if your opponent strikes you on the ground he'll snap your neck and kill you, but this is just a mean to an end, since your main goal ain't to kill your opponent but to get to the last screen you need to push to be devoured by the mythical serpent Nidhogg, hence the name of the game, and to do that you need to kill you enemy and  move forward through each screen, being lead to a fence-fueled tug of war. And the graphics, soundtrack and sound effects match the game perfectly and until now I didn't experienced any major flaws on the gameplay of the game which is fluid and easy to get the hang. The single-player can be fun enough, but the game really shines in the multiplayer, the local versus can make for a really neat party game. So scrap some cash and buy this gem.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												This game is a blast to play!  The singleplayer is fine, but the meat and potatoes of this game is when you're facing a human opponent either online or locally.  The online can use a bit of work because some matches can be pretty laggy.  However, when you do get in to a match and everything works, it really works.  Still, the netcode needs improvement and I hope the fixes for that come sooner rather than later.There's a lot of hidden depth to the gameplay as well.  You have to decide when it's right to let yourself die in order to respawn in front of your opponent before they make it to the next screen.  When is it the right time to make a break for it to get to the next screen?  When you decide to let yourself die in order to respawn as a barrier for your opponent, is there is even enough time for you to respawn in front of them?  Should I hold on to my sword, or should throw it and make a run for it hoping it distracts the opponent? These are some of the thoughts that will constantly be running through your head while playing this game and it's made all the more intense when facing off against a human opponent.I also really dig the old-school Atari 2600-esque look of the game.  The use of colours makes the levels look really nice and I just like the simplicity of it.  The super colourful neon blood is also prety great!The soundtrack to the game is also fantastic!  Each of the 4 levels in the game has a unique song that plays in the background and it makes the one on one battle so much more enjoyable.  I definitely recommend this game to anyone who wants a lot of local and online (when it's properly working 100% of the time) MP fun!

content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												A truly fun game with very smooth gameplay. There's not much singleplayer content other than fighting a line of swordmen with the difficulty increase per time you defeat the next in the row. The multiplayer seems to have a bit delay for now, other than that it's great fun killing your enemy. Your goal is to get to the right of the level and enter the next screen, while your enemy have to get to the left side of the screen. You are only able to move to the next scene when  you have the GO sign in the opposite corner of yourself, It's a tough process and can take a good amount of time if you're playing against a mighty fencer. There are various ways to kill and disarm your enemy or yourself :3You have 5 different ways to hold your sword, with different range depending on you're trying to target the enemies feet or head. The higher you aim, the longer range. The lower you aim, the shorter range. When holding the sword in the upper position, you'll be able to throw it (also when jumping in midair), hopefully killing your enemy or die trying... When you jump, you're able to strike downward, this is a great ability if you've lost your sword and still want to go offensive on your enemy. You can also roll and kick when approaching the player if his sword is in a high position, else you'll just die horribly by getting stacked in the chest or face. The sound effects makes it quite enjoyable to stick your sword through the chest of someone else and keeping it inside, making it "bleed"  more and enemy scream even longer is just very satisfying.The different set of levels gives the player a good amount of space to use his different moves and feature lots of movement to make the scenes more alive, the game does have music but it's quite ambient and might not get noticed because of the  screams coming from either you or your enemy..:CONCLUSION:.It's really good fun and plays great, the price point might be a bit high but there's online multiplayer which makes the price acceptable in my opinion. There's not much content for the single-player type and the online multi-player can be slighty laggy at times but based on being very unique, play very smooth and the gameplay have great combat, I would very much recommend this game.

Posted: June 24, 2014
												Nidhogg solely focus on a combat system, combining fencing and tug-of-war together to create a simple yet fun gameplay. There are a lot of options there to create a strategy. You can fight your opponent with rapier or goes unarmed, you can thrust, punch, parry, disarm opponent, throwing weapon, do a sweep attack, and even do a dive kick. Running away also a one good strategy here in Nidhogg for you to consider as the objective is to reach the goal not to defeat the opponent until he/she run out of life.Nidhogg's concept is good and the video that show is even help make it look very interesting.Anyway, one big flaw of Nighogg is a lacks of contents, especially in a lacks of solid single player content. The only thing you will find in a single player mode is a series of 16 AI opponents that not really different in terms of difficulty, pretty much the same. There are only 4 stages in the game as you can see in the video. No unloackable contents pretty much make this game suffer a scarceness of solid contents and no replay value.It is true that the core design of the game is quite interesting. I am able to enjoy a single player mode to some extent but that's that. Once I beat the single player mode I went to try multiplayer mode with someone, unfortunately online matchmaking show that no one playing Nidhogg online and none of my fried owned this game as well.I guess the game could deliver a better experience if you has a friend to play together offline or online but for a gamer who focus on single player experience I recommend you to avoid Nidhogg. Even with a 66% discount for this game is seem a little pricy to me after I bought it.

												This game is pure fun! It can't really be described, other than fast paced fencing-martial arts-divekicking-combat - oh yea, and you get eaten by a huge wyrm at the end of every level to top it all off. The combat system is unique, in that there is surprising depth for such a seemly short (and by short, I mean a ton of deaths every level. This game isn't exactly easy) single player game. Developing your own style really feels like you own it, and every time you die, you don't feel cheated. Multiplayer is where this game really shines, and it's really meant to be played against a human opponent, whether someone online or someone sitting beside you. The CPU opponents put up a great fight though, and it's perfect for developing your own style of play before you face off with a friend. The price is slightly high, for what this game is, but if you feel like it's something you might enjoy, I would say possibly wait for a sale if you are strapped for cash. That being said, I do not regret my purchase. To me personally, this game is worth it.

												Oooh, this is a clever little game we have here that essentially covers a 9 stage long map focusing on fencing and running for your life. Nidhogg is a tug-of-war game that relies on basic movement and attack mechanics (literally, there are 6 controls) to simulate fast-paced fencing and brawling combat in a race to be devoured by the beast called, "Nidhogg". number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												     The adrenaline will fly as you try to overtake your opponent in Nidhogg! The object of the game is to reach the other side of the map, to which there are seven sections; the only thing stopping you is your little set of legs and your adversary. There is a surprising amount of depth to this one on one side scroller, despite the only controls being jump, attack and the directions. You can hold your sword in three positions: high, medium, or low. Where you hold the sword dictates what attacks you will block.      All throughout you will have to make split-second decisions, and those decisions are what make the game so addicting. At times, you will be convinced that you have felled the enemy, only to be rolled into and killed. These are the defining moments of Nidhogg; while your jaw is on the floor from the surprise, your stinker of a roommate hoofs it to the goal.

Posted: January 16, 2014
												This game is pure fun! It can't really be described, other than fast paced fencing-martial arts-divekicking-combat - oh yea, and you get eaten by a huge wyrm at the end of every level to top it all off. The combat system is unique, in that there is surprising depth for such a seemly short (and by short, I mean a ton of deaths every level. This game isn't exactly easy) single player game. Developing your own style really feels like you own it, and every time you die, you don't feel cheated. Multiplayer is where this game really shines, and it's really meant to be played against a human opponent, whether someone online or someone sitting beside you. The CPU opponents put up a great fight though, and it's perfect for developing your own style of play before you face off with a friend. The price is slightly high, for what this game is, but if you feel like it's something you might enjoy, I would say possibly wait for a sale if you are strapped for cash. That being said, I do not regret my purchase. To me personally, this game is worth it.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												Nidhogg is nice for the first few hours within which you'll probably repeatedly fight the singleplayer AI until you release it's occasionally either far too stupid or far too difficult (it can do things that you simply cannot), at which point you'll probably feel experienced enough to try the multiplayer.It's at this point that the game completely falls apart. The multiplayer is consistently laggy and it always seems to take at least a few minutes to get into a match - if finding a game wasn't arduous enough, attempting to transfer your SP tactics to MP is nigh impossible since you'll find the controls simply aren't responsive enough. Nidhogg absolutely requires you to have quick reactions and MP makes this impossible.The Tournament mode is useless without at least two other experienced players able to use your computer (since it's local MP) and if you were looking to practice against the AI then enjoy having to play through the entire game just to get to a point you feel is difficult enough because you can't skip levels.Oh, and the super bright cloud level is absolutely horrible to look at, I personally can barely see anything. I wonder how exactly the development time on this game was spent when there are such obvious flaws (why would you choose a bright background when the player is bright yellow and the sword is white?)I do honestly like the gameplay but I can't in all good conscience recommend this game to anyone looking for a competitive multiplayer experience. Some cool stuff can happen but on average, Nidhogg will leave you simultaneously annoyed but wanting to play more since it could get better.

												For an indie game that has been on the radar for so long, sweeping up critical praise for years, there was a lot of expectation for this oddly titled game and it has delivered. Nidhogg has that quality that seems lost in most 3D AAA titles, and is becoming rarer even amongst 2D indie games. It gives you memories of titles as diverse as Flashback and the first Prince of Persia game, whilst the competitive play is on a par with classics such as Mario Kart, Unirally and Super Smash Brothers. I fear how many hours I could lose to the acid enduced lucid dream of a game and for that alone I must place it on the highest of pedestals along with the likes of only Speedrunners. This game justifies the price tag - Period. The animations are faultless, the levels well designed and engaging. The screenshots and video do not do this title justice. It needs playing.The only critique is a few spots of lag during online play, but the mode is still very playable and competitive.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												It's a fighting game, but not really: there are no "super" moves, power bars, or frame timings; just run, jump, and stab. It's easy to pick up and play, and within a few minutes you'll feel like you're accomplishing the most amazing series of maneuvers. There's no need to log 300 hrs of practice to get "good" here.I love the simplicity of it: movement, 5 "stances" (overhead, high, mid, low, crouch), a jump button, and an action button. That's it. Using combinations of those controls, you have access to a surprising variety of moves that help you push past a constantly respawning opponent, only to celebrate your victory by jumping into Níðhöggr's waiting maw.The one downside, though, is the price. $15 is crazy. $10 would've been MUCH better. I hope they continue to develop levels/content for this to help justify the price.There's a damn good reason this won so many IGF awards, and I'm glad it finally made it to a full release version. Thanks to the option to hold tournaments of up to 8 players, I can see this being an awesome party game, but hopefully they can flesh out the online multiplayer, as well as add more content, to keep people playing even after the party's over.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
tl;dr -> If you ever wanted to stab your friends in the face while avoiding jail time, get this game and invite them over. 11/10 awesome fencing simulator.I got this game when it was a Steam Daily Sale, and was very happy with my purchase. A fantastic party game to play with friends, both online and locally.If you like 1 versus 1 gameplay, fencing, and fast-paced action, then you will really enjoy this game.The aesthetics are very simple, but still good - the blood leakage effect whenever someone dies can result in the battlefield being painted in a variety of colors. The music and sounds are decent, but I prefer to play my own to add to the intensity of the combat. Controls are very simple, but mastering the combat system may take some practice. There is a quick tutorial that will help you learn everything you need to know. The learning curve is minimal - the most difficult thing being training yourself and your reflexes/reaction time. I've tried using both a controller and the keyboard, and either works perfectly - I personally prefer a controller.The gameplay is fast and relentless - your goal is to reach the opposite end of the map, while also preventing your opponent from doing the same. There are a series of areas to pass (the map is mirrored) before the "final area," and if you pass this area you will continue on to the winners section. You can lunge with your sword or punch/divekick if you are unarmed. Throwing your sword is risky, but may be fruitful in the right situation. You can pick up any dropped sword, and an area may have plenty of swords (and blood) on the ground if you and your opponent are rapidly killing each other. You can do tricks like disarming your opponent by hovering up or down on their sword, and you can also sweep their legs to drop them to the ground. The "right of way" arrow shows who can continue down the map, and this is provided to whoever has achieved the latest kill. There are situations where both players can die - mostly falling to your death - and the right of way will be reset to no one. An interesting concept - and advantage - of having the right of way is that you don't necessarily have to kill your opponent each time. Instead, you can also try to dodge them and just keep running down the map. To counter this, you need to run in the opposite direction in order to spawn in front of the person with the right of way. There is a singleplayer mode that is fairly challenging, as well as a tournament mode (or just straight up versus, both online and local). Overall, the game is a fantastic party game that is very easy to learn and begin playing. Definitely recommend!Cheers,DJSF @DJSF's Rogue Reviews

												Nidhogg, where do I start. Not much content, graphics simple yet fitting, laggy multiplayer, a seemingly boring soundtrack, and pretty decent combat. Fifteen dollars is not worth the lack of content this game provides, unless you have friends who live in your house, as tournaments are only local. The lack of maps is another downside to this game, but can be overlooked, as the maps included do have noticable differences. Swordplay is interesting, and takes some work to master. Matchmaking turns out to be horrendous unless you have friends to play with, as the matchmaking takes ten minutes to find a match, but when you do it is enjoyable. The gameplay provided is minimal, but what is provided is enjoyable. Overall, this title is not one for those who don't wish to put the work in to learn to master the excellent swordplay presented to them, but fifteen dollars is too much, this game is worth five or less.If however you do decide to purchase this game, watch the first duel in this video, as it shows all the tricks needed to suceed in Nidhogg-https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XWMlU8eKOsg

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												Nidhogg is a very simplistic representation of fencing where the goal is to reach the opponent's start point and get eaten by some giant creature presumably called the Nidhogg. The gameplay has a bit of a tug-of-war feel to it as dead players respawn a bit further back from where they were slain meaning you have to continuously battle all the way to the end without failing to win. Combat consists of moving your blade up/down, thrusting, rolling, throwing the blade, and jump kicks, combinations of which can be used to confuse and disable your opponent, setting them up for the kill. Once you kill an opponent, you gain the right of way and place him on the defensive, meaning that if you were to jump over him and continue towards his start, he would have to pursue you or allow himself to be scrolled off and respawn in front of you.Due to the overall simplicity of the game and small number of levels, it seems to suit itself more towards multiplayer than single player which is unfortunate because the multiplayer can get downright unplayable due to latency causing your inputs to get ignored or delayed. Additionally the controls can be awkward when shifting between stances not to mention you risk throwing your sword when shifting to stab high from a mid-stance. I originally had a bit more positive of a review for this game but after re-playing it I decided to drop my recommendation since the content is really lacking and not worth the base price (or really even the sale price).

content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												Nidhogg is absurdly fun.  The combat is similar to Divekick with its simple controls and surprising amount of depth in combat.  Once you kill your opponent you'll only have a few seconds to get as far as you can before you respawn.  Then you must decide if you're gonna take down your opponent again or try to run past him and go for the goal Randy Moss style.Nidhogg is not without its issues though.  There's nothing for PC specific options aside from volume sliders and the online play has a few issues which could potentially be a dealbreaker.Creating a lobby at first was an exercise in frustration.  The invite friends list is not alphabatized which isn't a huge deal if you don't have many Steam friends, but I have 200+ and it added extra time to what should be a simple process.  Once you invite someone the other person doesn't get a Steam notification, they have to hit "Join Game" from Steam friends.  There's no indication that you have to do this either.  Once you have this all figured out it works, but come on.  These are basic menu functions in any online game.In the games I played with my friend the host had a huge advantage because of latency, we had to swap hosting every few rounds to make it fair.  If you can play locally then you won't have to deal with this.  It's a perfect couch game if you are thinking of a Steambox solution.Despite my complaints about the game I've really enjoyed it so far, though with the issues I've mentioned above it's a little hard to recommend at full price.  Buy it on sale for sure.TL;DR version:  Buy if you have a friend to play with and can deal with a few online issues.EDIT1/14/2014 - The invite system works with Steam properly now, but the friends list in game is still not in alphabetical order.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
												I personally loved this game, it encompasses so much that I use to love as a child all in one package.The game plays like a mix between Marshmellow Duels (an old DOS based Super smash Brlos styled game) and Prince of Persia Classic (I doubt this needs exaplining)The game might look simple and to be honest it is and it isn't. The amazing thing about this game is when you play as a noob with another noob you can pretty much have fun screwing up togther. If you are both hardcore u can stay minutes on one level, and feel your adrenaline rush.Now if you play as a noob against a good player expect the match to be over ina  matter of seconds in some cases. The game is simple but it's also very skill friendly, so if your good > bad players and luck plays very little here.There are only a hand full of levels but you will want to keep playing them over and over again. The online and local multiplayer is where the game shines. It turns this great game into a fantastic game. You will only play with Ai when you have no internet or people over, other than that you will never want to vs ai again.9.0/10 at full price9.5/10 on saleThe reason for different scores is because the game is fairly expensive for what it offers, but the mechanics are so clean and simple that it can make up for it even at full price for some.If your not a fan of retro or fencing styled games (ninja fencing in this case) don't bother with this game. It's graphics are charming to those that can appreciate them, and the game play to those that love the genre:)

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												Nidhogg is a down right brutal fighting game that is easy to learn but difficult to master. There are only a few moves you can do, but this means it's less of a button smash than the likes of Street Fighter. It also means that it can be anybody's game, and many times matches will go for minutes on end because there are so many comebacks.The presentation is very slick. The fighters and their animations stand out well enough to keep the focus on the action, but the backgrounds can be as pretty as ever, even though they are largely simple. The music is brilliantly fitted to every stage, so it's all wrapped up with a neat little bow.The singleplayer will take anywhere between 30 minutes to an hour to complete, but the real heart of this game is in the multiplayer. The store page cites a lot of issues with online multiplayer, yet I haven't had any issues outside of one match where there was some lag. Either way you owe it to yourself to play this with local multiplayer instead, to see the reactions of your opponents.It's more worth $10 in my opinion, but if you can find this on a sale, there's no doubt that you should pick it up.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												This game is the♥♥♥♥♥♥It's a fast-paced two-player dueling game. You can fence madly, cartwheel away, throw your rapier, somersault through the air, snatch a rapier off the ground and skewer your opponent through the guts, you can rush unarmed at your opponent only to roll beneath his drawn rapier at the last moment, trip him with  a sweep of the leg, tear his heart out, grab his rapier and keep running. You can pull off all kinds of insane stunts, and I can't help but laugh every time. This gameplay is accompanied by an equally frenzied soundtrack and trippy neon graphics. The great art direction and style of this game is undeniable.Multiplayer is online and local, and there is also a singleplayer mode where you fight a computer opponent. It's not as fun as desperately outsmarting a human opponent. The online multiplayer introduces a ton of lag and causes many maneuvers to be impossible to pull off. That said, I've been mainly playing online opponents (haven't had the chance to play local yet), and it's been some of the most exhilarating multiplayer gameplay I've experienced, despite the lag.There aren't many games where you can do a somersault, but this is one of them. It feels great.On the downside, there are only 4 stages. What you'll get out of this game will depend on how much you put into it and on the people you play against. Best suited for playing with friends, two controllers and a tv.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Nidhogg is perfect example that fighting games can offer more variety than what most of its competition would lead to believe.The game is ultimately a game of tag with the objective being to run to your goal. You become "it" when you defeat your opponent or they suicide. Whenever you die or trail off-screen, you will generally respawn in your opponent's path a few moments later. When you spawn, you are given a fencing sword to use in combat with the other player, but you can also fight unarmed if you throw your sword or you can also pick-up a sword dropped earlier on that section of the stage map. There is a decent variety of options that are simplistic in execution but add a lot of depth to the game, especially when used in conjunction with the terrain of the stage.I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys versus multiplayer games, not just fans of the fighting game genre.

												Judging from the videos (and user reviews) I thought that this could be a very fun game for vs matches with people. That's why I decided to support the developers (even though the price seemed a bit high). The problem here is that first and foremost I bought having in my mind that this game will provide a very fun experience in online multiplayer, trying to beat someone in one-on-one fights. I'm certain that if it worked it would be extremely fun. But that's a BIG if.In the description of the game it says that it supports online matches, and this is the main (if not the only) reason that I bought the game. The severe lag in every single match makes this game practically unplayable in the online environment. It's worth also mentioning that the single player mode can be finished in less than half hour and certainly isn't a mode worthy of the price tag.Because of the broken online multiplayer mode I feel ripped off by this game, considering that I payed 12 euros mainly for a feature advertised that isn't working.

Posted: January 14, 2014
												Bah. I want to like Nidhogg, but the arbitrariness of the outcome of the fencing leaves me frequently frustrated. Sometimes you can disarm an opponent and run him right through, only to find the kill doesn't register. The AI is particularly dangerous when disarmed - it will almost always respond with a lightning-quick head-kick, then steal your epee and skewer you with it, all in the split second after you've sent his own weapon spinning!I'm also puzzled by what governs the respawning time - sometimes opponents will return almost immediately, while at other times there's a long wait.Since this core duelling element is really all there is to the game, you'd think it would be much, much tighter. For £10, I was expecting either a lot more variation or a simple mechanic honed to perfection, but you don't really get either.

												This game has a lot of potential.It's a fun and frantic dueling game with simple pixel graphics. The game is a lot of fun when played with others wether online or  locally. There are some glaring problems though. It's controller support is lacking as I can only get my wired X360 controller to work which just won't cut it for such a precise game. The perfect controller for this game is a USB NES controller which for some reason isn't supported at all.This game has been in development for like 4 years and it's not like it's very advanced or deep. Knowing this and seeing low quality graphics, the lack of digital controller support and bugs all over the place I can not recommend this game at $15 or even at it's sale price. 												Literally unplayable online. The problem is most likely on my end, but I get 500 ms ping and 500 ms input delay when I try matchmaking.But that's fine, I mean, that's the LEAST of netcode related issues for me. Get this: I don't know if it's latency related, my computer's net name related, my connection type related, the DNS server I'm using or whatever, BUT MY FPS DROPS TO LITERAL SLIDESHOW LEVEL IN MULTIPLAYER. And I mean SLIDESHOW, like 3 freaking frames a second.Barely anybody is trying to play online, so I guess I'm not the only one having this issue.What the hell, dude? I knew netcode is absolute garbage in this game, but then I heard an update fixed it somewhat. How bad it must have been to begin with if THIS is the "fixed" netcode? I cannot even begin to imagine.PC gaming wiki doesn't tell me how to fix this problem, and it's not in the FAQ on steam forums. Probably won't refund it on an off chance I'll play this locally one day, got it dirt cheap anyway. Game's reasonably fun even against AI opponents, who get stupidly hard after you cycle through 4 maps this game has.And another funny thing happened: I bought 2 copies of this game, and offered it to 5 of my steam friends who were online at that moment. Nobody wanted to accept it. Steam users? Declining free games? I wonder why that is.TL;DR: great game in here somewhere, brilliant idea killed in its infancy by the ♥♥♥♥♥iest netcode known to man. If you're not a friendless loser like myself you've probably played this do death in local versus mode already.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												The game's polished as could be hoped for, and is reasonably good detecting hits (in local games) and giving a variety of environments to fight in (doors, tall grass, clouds, etc). It's different, for sure. And if you're more into playing something new rather than playing something that you'd like to love forever, Nidhogg is the game for you, and I recommend it.Unfortunately for anyone who wants to be competitive, or has played games for more than a few years, the achilles heel of Nidhogg is its controls. They're sloppy. It's very difficult to translate your decisions into game actions, and generally leads to both players in the game twisting their faces and going "what? Why is it doing that? That's not what I'm doing. Are you seeing this?"In Nidhogg, there are only six buttons. left/right/up/down, jump, and lunge. Left/right and jump/lunge are pretty straightforward - they only do one action apiece. They move you left/right, or they jump or lunge you. No ambiguity. However, up/down are extremely overloaded. They toggle the state of your guard (low, mid, high) as well as allow you to throw your sword (up + lunge), *and* allow you to crouch (down, but only from a low guard), *and* roll (down, but only while sprinting). The problem with this is it leads to needing to combine too many identical keys for totally different actions. You'll find that the game decides you wanted to throw your sword, even though you only tapped up to go to a high guard to lunge at your opponent. Or it will dutifully force you into a crouch when you just wanted to go between low guard and midguard. There doesn't seem to be event queueing, so while you wait for one animation to finish, any further input is discarded. This means that if you're trying to rapidly go between high and mid guards, more often than not you'll press the keys *too fast* and get stuck between a high guard and the "throwing stance". Don't believe me? Make a macro and try going between guards to quickly.It's an intentional design, but it seems wrongheaded. A better system would have been to have a button dedicated to throwing the sword, a button specific to crouching, and allow modifier keys to go between guards. e.g., right trigger moves you into a high guard, left trigger to a low guard, and if neither are held down, then you're in a midguard. Throwing would be a separate key, and crouching could be opposite the jump key. With this setup, every decision you make can be unambiguously done with two keys, tops.Even if the designers wanted the default behavior to be limiting and sloppy, they could have at least given more thought to the keybindings - to at least give players the *option* of having the sort of system i mentioned above. The controls are so crusted together than you can't even bind mouse buttons to game actions. Aren't we on PCs? Isn't part of the point of PC to have customization and playstyle adjustments?If you're determined to like the game, you can always get used to the controls and hope they don't bite you too often. I'm sure that with ten or fifteen hours, anyone could get used to the game's quirks. But ask yourself if you really want to go through that.

They're sloppy. It's very difficult to translate your decisions into game actions, and generally leads to both players in the game twisting their faces and going "what? Why is it doing that? That's not what I'm doing. Are you seeing this?"In Nidhogg, there are only six buttons. left/right/up/down, jump, and lunge. Left/right and jump/lunge are pretty straightforward - they only do one action apiece. They move you left/right, or they jump or lunge you. No ambiguity. However, up/down are extremely overloaded. They toggle the state of your guard (low, mid, high) as well as allow you to throw your sword (up + lunge), *and* allow you to crouch (down, but only from a low guard), *and* roll (down, but only while sprinting). The problem with this is it leads to needing to combine too many identical keys for totally different actions. You'll find that the game decides you wanted to throw your sword, even though you only tapped up to go to a high guard to lunge at your opponent. Or it will dutifully force you into a crouch when you just wanted to go between low guard and midguard. There doesn't seem to be event queueing, so while you wait for one animation to finish, any further input is discarded. This means that if you're trying to rapidly go between high and mid guards, more often than not you'll press the keys *too fast* and get stuck between a high guard and the "throwing stance". Don't believe me? Make a macro and try going between guards to quickly.It's an intentional design, but it seems wrongheaded. A better system would have been to have a button dedicated to throwing the sword, a button specific to crouching, and allow modifier keys to go between guards. e.g., right trigger moves you into a high guard, left trigger to a low guard, and if neither are held down, then you're in a midguard. Throwing would be a separate key, and crouching could be opposite the jump key. With this setup, every decision you make can be unambiguously done with two keys, tops.Even if the designers wanted the default behavior to be limiting and sloppy, they could have at least given more thought to the keybindings - to at least give players the *option* of having the sort of system i mentioned above. The controls are so crusted together than you can't even bind mouse buttons to game actions. Aren't we on PCs? Isn't part of the point of PC to have customization and playstyle adjustments?If you're determined to like the game, you can always get used to the controls and hope they don't bite you too often. I'm sure that with ten or fifteen hours, anyone could get used to the game's quirks. But ask yourself if you really want to go through that.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												Nidhogg is a minimalist game at a MAXIMUM price. The core concept of the game is very sound, with sword fighting mechanics that feel balanced and fun. However, the amount of content you get for $15 is absolutely appalling. There is a 30 minute single player mode with no story or explanation of what a Nidhogg is, in fact there is no story to the game whatsoever. Every character is the same with no unique stats or abilities, and there are only 4 stages to play on. Some variety can be found in multiplayer, where you can set up custom rules like low gravity, sudden death, and no swords... but none of those options are available in online matches. There is also only one game type, albeit a fun and exciting one. Online is fun, but about 1 out of 10 matches suffer from lag, which is absolutely ridiculous for a game this simple. There is a leaderboard only for times clearing single player, the game does not track your win/lose record, you can't even pick the color of your character online... it's always yellow vs orange. No ranking, nothing to unlock. Offline multiplayer is far better if you have a group to play with... it's definitely a fantastic party game, but could have been so much more. Nidhog doesn't even have a widescreen mode or any resolution options, so if you are playing on a widescreen monitor or TV, you will have black bars on each side. Thankfully the music is fantastic, because you'll be hearing it over and over again on the same four stages. Controller support is also very limited, the game will recognize a Xbox 360 controller, but fails to register my Mad Catz Fightstick Pro (although I can get it to work using joy2key). Nidhog feels like an early access game, and certainly does nothing to justify a $15 price tag. I got the game at 20% off and I still regret it. This will be my first and last Messhof game.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
												When I first heard about Nidhogg, it sounded like a dream. There were whispers in multipayer communities about a rise of local multiplayer games that truly captured the imagination. The rise of games like Samurai Gunn and Towerfall Ascension have been popping up in the gaming scene, and it has been much better for it. Nidhogg, much like the aformentioned titles, offers that same sort of experience to players.Nidhogg could be describe as a combat simulator, but of the flashy variety. It offers various levels of play with a basic control scheme. At first glance the game seems a little lacking in levels, but once you dive in the game reveals it's levels of depth. In some regards it seems similar to the high level of play found in a Smash Bros Melee game. Some levels provide a "gimmick" to playing them, as others offer simplicity. The Stages, Castle and Mines, offer the most straightforward approach to combat, while other levels lik Clouds and Wilds offer more strategic play for more wilely players.When picking up the game, it's important to ask why you're doing it. This is not for the solitary experience, certainly not worth the price point. Get some friends together and have yourself a classic gaming night.

												I would highly recommend Nidhogg, but only if you have friends to play with locally. It's some of the most fun I've had playing local multiplayer, but the online doesn't work terribly well. The game is easy to pick up and you can teach someone to play in 15 seconds, but it's relatively deep and there is a lot to the combat, especially if both players have gotten good at it. Very few times have I felt I lost because of chance, or felt the game was unfair to me. I always lost because I made a mistake, or I didn't react fast enough. There isn't much content in the game though, as there are only four stages and the singleplayer is just a 'fight a.i. opponents until you lose, or beat them all' game and there aren't any additional modes. Unless you plan on having friends over to play a lot, I'd be hesitant to buy the game at it's full $15 dollar price tag. If you can pick it up on sale, or if you play local multiplayer a lot, then go for it.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												 Nidhogg is a game that has been wowing the tournament crowds for a little while and now the rest of us get a chance to see what all the fuss is about. A one on one fencing the game, it is a pure test of skill against an opponent much in the same way Street Fighter or IK+ is. On the service Nidhogg is a simple game. You have to get your fencer to run across the level and reach your opponents end zone. Here you are eaten by the big worm Nidhogg thing and pronounced the winner. In order to do this you need to repeatedly best your enemy as you progress. Starting in the middle of the level you need to kill your opponent and run, after a short time your opponent will respawn and you fight again. If your opponent kills you they can then run the opposite direction in an attempt to regain ground.There are four levels to fight on which offer different environmental challenges and obstacles to use to your advantage. The castle has rooms and pits, so you can try and force your opponent to jump a pit and land on your sword or stay in a room so they can’t jump over you. The mine has a low ceiling which nullifies the ability to throw the sword or jump over your opponent, The clouds have disappearing ledges and the wilderness has platforms and long grass which allow for more manoeuvring and hiding.The only stage that doesn’t really work is the cloud stage as it’s just a bit much for your eyes to deal with; it’s also a bit dull compared to the others. The Wilderness reminded us of a 2D version of Bushido Blade which is certainly no bad thing at all.The fencer has a range of moves and techniques at their disposal. They can roll, cartwheel and jump which can be used to try and sneak past opponents if they have their sword at the wrong height. You can also perform a dive kick which knocks opponents over and makes them drop their sword. When an opponent is on the ground death can be dealt via a swift neck break. With the sword in hand you can thrust at three different heights. This works in a rock, paper, scissors kind of way and also defends against things like dive kicks depending on where you have the sword set. If you wish you can also throw your sword, however, if it’s parried you then leave yourself open to almost certain death.These basic moves form the crux of your sword fighting strategy and can be used in a number of different ways in order to best your opponent. If you are feeling super confident you can also disarm your opponent by moving your sword to the correct position at the exact right moment. Get this wrong though and you will find your own sword flying away.Essentially, this is a two player game and anyone going into it expecting a lengthy single player component will be disappointed. Single player acts as an arcade mode where you continually square off against computer controlled opponents on the games four levels. It’s practice for multiplayer and while a nice distraction it will only last you half an hour or so.The game uses a bright, 8-bit styled, colour palette to build its world. The colour scheme is garish but somehow seems to work. As a fencer is slain they explode into coloured dots and quickly begin to cover the arena in pixelated blood. It helps to highlight where the choke points are in each level as well as provide some visual flair.There’s no denying that Nidhogg is an excellent two player experience. It provides the same sort of adrenaline rush as all the best one on one fighting games and the mechanics work really well. However, we can’t help but feel that more could have been done here. There is certainly scope for a roaring Prince of Persia or Defender of the Crown style single player adventure. Even something like taking the Blood Valley (it’s an old, bad, 8 bit game), template and adding the superior gameplay of Nidhogg could work. Another option would be to have more stages. Having just four levels does make the package feel a little sparse. You could have had stages requiring some basic climbing or less footholds etc. Anyone who plays the game is going to have a great time and this is some of the best multiplayer action around at the minute. However, it could have been much more fleshed out in both single and multiplayer. The mechanics are great; we just hope there’s some further development of the other elements in the future as it could lead to something really special.Overall 7/10

												This game is great. Ridiculously simple, yet deceptively challenging, Nidhogg provides an experience like no other: the thrill of stabbing your silhouette-man opponent in the face so you can get eaten by a giant worm... thing.Seriously though, the game is very good. I've seen virtually no fencing games, so this game is in a very small category, but it does capture the feel of a sword duel very well; the waiting, positioning your sword for an advantage, looking for an opening to strike like lightning. I would know; I'm a fencer.The controls are quite simple, but there is a lot you can do with those six buttons. The tug-of-war mechanic is pretty clever, and adds a nice level of tension to the swordplay. If you screw up, your opponent could make a straight run to the end, virtually unopposed.The graphics are not impressive, but that should be obvious from the screenshots. The art style is interesting enough, if not terribly complex. However, the main focus of the game is the swordplay, so the visuals are not important in the slightest. in fact, something more realistic might actually detract from the experience.All in all, Nidhogg is a very good game. Definitely a solid 8 impalings out of 10. I personally think it's worth the $14.99. I've spent that much to see a two-hour movie, and this game can easily give me much more entertainment value for at least that long. Probably longer. I highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Nidhogg is what would happen if you took a fencing game, a tug-of-war game, and Towerfall and blended them all together. It's got the positioning and strategy of fencing, the back and forth momentum swings of tug-of-war, and the frenzied pace of Towerfall. Just like Ken Griffey Jr., it's a great game to check out if you and a friend want a quick laugh and to yell obscenities at each other while playing a fun game.The basic goal of Nidhogg is to get from one end of the screen to the other. There are always two players, yellow and orange. The yellow player wants to move to the right, and the orange player wants to move to the left. But in order to progress to the left or right, your player has to have control of the camera. The game will always begin in a neutral position. The camera is initially in a fixed position and camera control is rewarded to the first player who gets a kill. You can kill an opponent by stabbing them with your sword, throwing your sword at them, snapping their neck while they're knocked down, or by pushing your opponent into a stage hazard. As soon as you get control of the camera, you'll want to frantically run to the left or right, depending on which color player you are. But your opponent will be constantly respawning in your path to try and kill you, take control of the camera and push back in the opposite direction. Once you reach the end of the stage, you win, and are rewarded by being eaten by the giant flying worm known as the Nidhogg. Yeah.The pace of the game is very fast, and matches will usually last under a minute or two. Even though battles with your opponent happen very quickly, there's a little bit of rock-paper-scissors strategy with each encounter. You can approach traditionally with your sword, go in high for a divekick, or go in low and try to sweep the leg and snap the neck. There are also three fencing elevations you can hold your sword: low medium and high. Holding your sword low will protect against leg sweeps, but leave you open to divekicks and sword throws. Holding your sword high will protect against sword throws, but leave you open to leg sweeps. If you get disarmed or throw your sword, you will be able to run faster, but you will have fewer options. You can only attack with divekicks or leg sweeps, so often the best option is to just try to jump over your opponent. You can try to strategically analyze each of these options and try to predict what your opponent will do, but everything happens so quickly that you barely have time to think before one of you is already dead. You never really get a sense of negative punishment though, the quick respawning and fast pace of the game will only allow you to shout one quick profane phrase at your opponent before you're right back in the game to try again.The art style and music perfectly complement the gameplay of Nidhogg. There are four playable stages and each have frenetic and constantly changing background artwork. The artwork really serves to highlight the frantic and urgent pace of the gameplay. Same with the soundtrack. Most of the songs in the soundtrack have an eerie synthesized sound accompanied by an unpredictable and wild drum track. It really is the gameplay expressed through music. Each time a character dies, they explode into puddle of orange or yellow paint which flies all over the level at the point at which a character was killed. If you really get a deadlock where each player keeps pushing back and forth at the same position, you get a crazy looking orange and yellow bloodbath. It's pretty cool looking. The pixelated animations of the character models are great too. Some of the death animations are especially funny and they're accompanied by great over-exaggerated death screams. Great example of simple but awesome design in the audio/visualsNidhogg is an excellent example of a great game that will probably only ever get made in the indie space. The elevator pitch for this game is way too insane to be taken seriously by an executive and the scope of the game is too small for a large company to bother spending resources developing it. I'm really happy that there's a huge boom of really interesting and creative ideas coming from all of these amazing indie games like Nidhogg right now.Nidhogg is a weird, fast and crazy good time if you and a friend are looking for a game to play. There's even a bunch of crazy bonus setting like low gravity mode or hyper-speed mode you can toggle in the settings if you get tired of the basic game. The scope of Nidhogg is small, but the gameplay is good and the replay value is high. I'd recommend checking it out.For more game reviews, check out http://whatisjamesplaying.blogspot.com/

content:
Posted: March 27, 2016
												First of all, this game is not worth anywhere near a tenner. Absolutely not. There are four maps for god’s sake and one game type. That’s the entire game. It’s worth no more than five quid at best.Ok, so right off the bat, this game is fun. It is simple to understand, difficult to master, as all great games are, or should be. Playing with a friend is great, playing local multiplayer is even better. I have no quarrels with the game itself, what I have a problem with is how unplayably unfair it can be really randomly. I genuinely think this could be an esport if it had more depth and they fixed the broken AS ALL HELL  spawning system. The worst thing it does is when it spawns an enemy right in front of you as you’re walking and you just immediately die. This can loose you the single player tournament almost instantly and it’s infuriating. What really takes you out of the game is how outlandishly stupid the AI enemies are. Here is a prime example: you’re stood on a conveyor belt that is feeding into a pit from left to right. Your enemy is on the right of the conveyor and will fall in if he doesn’t move. You can guess where I’m going with this. They never move, they just fall. Any difficulty, any enemy, every time. Incredible. At higher levels, the best way to beat the game is to abuse this stupidity. Make the AI throw swords at ledges designed specifically to stop sword throwing (The only exception is the tunnel section of the mines level, AI rarely throw swords there.)What annoys me most  is that this could be an incredible game. Stupidly easy to understand and it’s really easy to tell if you’re at the same level as someone else. All the games play out like a tug-of-war and it’s just begging to be played competitively but it never will because it’s unfinished.All-in-all, I would recommend picking this game up when it’s on a good sale. Don’t pay more than half the RRP.Sidenote: Imagine if this game was f2p and it had hats. It would make millions in days.
