content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												Nidhogg is a deeply tactical fighting game that's been distilled down to its very core. The simple graphics, distilled game mechanics and ultimately satisfying battles makes Nidhogg simple to pick up but incredibly difficult to master. The single player is a great introduction to the various tactics that you (and other players) can use, preparing you for the ultimate showdown with your opponent sitting right beside you. It might not draw me in as much as Soul Calibur did but it's a great fix for someone who's been aching for a decent fighter for a while.Read my full review here: http://www.therefinedgeek.com.au/index.php/2014/02/21/nidhogg-surprisingly-tactical/

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												Fast paced combat, colorful visuals, and weird but surprisingly catchy music bundled up in an ultimately surreal package. Battles are intense bouts of skill, twitch, and a little bit of luck, making for a great experience in both online and offline multiplayer. The elements of the game that are actually game I cannot recommend enough.The biggest flaw in my opinion is the lack of content. A measley four maps make up your stage selection, and aside from a few entertaining variant modes (boomerang blades being my personal favorite), the gameplay is more or less static from match to match. A smaller issue is trying to share a keyboard when playing offline multiplayer where the game truly shines, but that shouldn't be a problem for anyone with a USB controller.In conclusion, Nidhogg is a strange little indie game that accomplished what it set out to do: be fun. It's definitely worth a look, and if you can enjoy the dreamlike graphics and sound, more than worth your time and money.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												 Nidhogg is a game that has been wowing the tournament crowds for a little while and now the rest of us get a chance to see what all the fuss is about. A one on one fencing the game, it is a pure test of skill against an opponent much in the same way Street Fighter or IK+ is. On the service Nidhogg is a simple game. You have to get your fencer to run across the level and reach your opponents end zone. Here you are eaten by the big worm Nidhogg thing and pronounced the winner. In order to do this you need to repeatedly best your enemy as you progress. Starting in the middle of the level you need to kill your opponent and run, after a short time your opponent will respawn and you fight again. If your opponent kills you they can then run the opposite direction in an attempt to regain ground.There are four levels to fight on which offer different environmental challenges and obstacles to use to your advantage. The castle has rooms and pits, so you can try and force your opponent to jump a pit and land on your sword or stay in a room so they can’t jump over you. The mine has a low ceiling which nullifies the ability to throw the sword or jump over your opponent, The clouds have disappearing ledges and the wilderness has platforms and long grass which allow for more manoeuvring and hiding.The only stage that doesn’t really work is the cloud stage as it’s just a bit much for your eyes to deal with; it’s also a bit dull compared to the others. The Wilderness reminded us of a 2D version of Bushido Blade which is certainly no bad thing at all.The fencer has a range of moves and techniques at their disposal. They can roll, cartwheel and jump which can be used to try and sneak past opponents if they have their sword at the wrong height. You can also perform a dive kick which knocks opponents over and makes them drop their sword. When an opponent is on the ground death can be dealt via a swift neck break. With the sword in hand you can thrust at three different heights. This works in a rock, paper, scissors kind of way and also defends against things like dive kicks depending on where you have the sword set. If you wish you can also throw your sword, however, if it’s parried you then leave yourself open to almost certain death.These basic moves form the crux of your sword fighting strategy and can be used in a number of different ways in order to best your opponent. If you are feeling super confident you can also disarm your opponent by moving your sword to the correct position at the exact right moment. Get this wrong though and you will find your own sword flying away.Essentially, this is a two player game and anyone going into it expecting a lengthy single player component will be disappointed. Single player acts as an arcade mode where you continually square off against computer controlled opponents on the games four levels. It’s practice for multiplayer and while a nice distraction it will only last you half an hour or so.The game uses a bright, 8-bit styled, colour palette to build its world. The colour scheme is garish but somehow seems to work. As a fencer is slain they explode into coloured dots and quickly begin to cover the arena in pixelated blood. It helps to highlight where the choke points are in each level as well as provide some visual flair.There’s no denying that Nidhogg is an excellent two player experience. It provides the same sort of adrenaline rush as all the best one on one fighting games and the mechanics work really well. However, we can’t help but feel that more could have been done here. There is certainly scope for a roaring Prince of Persia or Defender of the Crown style single player adventure. Even something like taking the Blood Valley (it’s an old, bad, 8 bit game), template and adding the superior gameplay of Nidhogg could work. Another option would be to have more stages. Having just four levels does make the package feel a little sparse. You could have had stages requiring some basic climbing or less footholds etc. Anyone who plays the game is going to have a great time and this is some of the best multiplayer action around at the minute. However, it could have been much more fleshed out in both single and multiplayer. The mechanics are great; we just hope there’s some further development of the other elements in the future as it could lead to something really special.Overall 7/10

												you find yourself at the final stage. You throw your sword in an all out attempt to dispatch your enemy and advance, but he throws his as well. Now, both disarmed, you both stand still, neither side daring to make the first move. With victory within reach you run and roll into your opponent hoping to sweep and knock him down, leaving him vulnerable. It only takes a fraction of a second for them to figure out your plan and responds with a dicekick, knocking you down momentarily. A frantic balls to the wall fist fight ensues until you finally knock your friend down and rip their still beating heart from their chest cavity. You run to the next screen, a crowd of spectators cheer you on, as you are eaten by a dragon, this is victory.Nidhogg is one of those games you can sit down with your friends and play and just have a good time. Tension is the name of the game where twitch reflexes and cunning tactics reign supreme. Nidhogg is an incredibly tight and precise game where zero ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t flies, and I think that's it's greatest strength. Knowing that you and your friend and playing on a completely level field where the skill of the player  dictates the outcome of the match. 												This game is fantastic. It brings back not just the nostalgia of playing heated matches with your friends on the couch, but also the pure skill and difficulty to truly master the game. This is not something that will give you instant gratification while holding your hand the whole way, like most games that are released nowadays seem to do, and yet anyone can pick it up and play it within minutes. It has to be said that those who bought this game expecting a single-player experience, or a game with a lot of combos and superficial depth, are going to be disappointed. Since the beginning of development, the game was, in my opinion, clearly focused on local multiplayer. This was meant to be a party game, or something that you and your friends could enjoy giving each other grief over on those late nights. I am pretty old school, and have gotten weary of the online matchmaking systems that most games implement - you just can't be certain you will be paired with someone that will make the game enjoyable for you. If you really want to have fun, you should be playing with your real friends anyways. And if that's your opinion on gaming as well, do yourself and your friends a favor - buy this game. It is absolutely worth it.

Posted: January 26, 2014
												I had the pleasure of watching the Game Grumps and Polaris play Nidhogg and I must say I was watching each tournament they had up from start to finish. Nidhogg is a fast paced game that can get intense when playing with friends. The controls are incredibly simple: Move, jump, and attack. However, what seems like a simple control scheme turns into a difficult tug-of-war between the two players. Parrying, diving, throwing your sword. There are many ways to win, and the player in the lead can suddenly get killed and be forced to catch up. Have a couple of controllers? Grab some friends and watch the fencing-antics!
